title: Running a single simulation
text: demo use data synthetic database mapped OMOP-CDM. can download database link.database 1-million person sample SynPUF (Synthetic Public Use Files), converted OMOP Common Data Model. provided DuckDB format, can run locally machine using R duckdb package.

title: Running a single simulation
text: first step need extract cohorts interest. example, use 4 exposure cohorts, namely, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, simvastatin. extract cohorts database need execute following code. Note packages DBI CohortConstructor glue need installed first.
code: connection <- DBI::dbConnect(   duckdb::duckdb(),   dbdir = "database-1M_filtered.duckdb" )  cdm <- CDMConnector::cdmFromCon(   con = connection,   cdmSchema = "main",   writeSchema = c(prefix = "demo_", schema = "main") )  conceptListExposures <- list(   lisinopril = 19080128,   hydrochlorothiazide = 19078106,   amlodipine = 19073094,   simvastatin = 1539463 )  cdm |>   CohortConstructor::conceptCohort(     conceptSet = conceptListExposures,     exit = "event_end_date",     name = "exposures"   )

title: Running a single simulation
text: Similarly, can define outcome cohorts analyses. , use 40 frequent conditions database. identify frequent conditions can run: , can extract concept cohorts : successfully running previous code snippets, created two new tables demo database named demo_exposures demo_outcomes. Finally, ’s best practice make sure disconnect database:
code: sql_query <- "   SELECT co.condition_concept_id, c.concept_name,     COUNT(DISTINCT condition_occurrence_id) n   FROM condition_occurrence co   JOIN concept c ON co.condition_concept_id = c.concept_id   GROUP BY co.condition_concept_id, c.concept_name   ORDER BY n DESC   LIMIT 40; "  outcomes <- DBI::dbGetQuery(connection, sql_query) conceptListOutcomes <- outcomes |>   dplyr::transmute(     name = paste("outcome", condition_concept_id, sep = "_"),     value = condition_concept_id )  |>   tibble::deframe()  |>   as.list()       cdm |>   CohortConstructor::conceptCohort(     conceptSet = conceptListOutcomes,     exit = "event_start_date",     name = "outcomes" ) DBI::dbDisconnect(connection)

title: Running a single simulation
text: Now, can proceed setting simulation study. first step train outcome models later used generate outcome times every patient. , first need decide whether entire database exposure cohorts used fitting models. case, entire database used. need generate new cohort table target cohort prediction model stored. can running following code: Since entire database used, code makes sure every patient time risk starts 1 year observation period start date time risk limited 15 years. , outcome models can fitted using following code. First, set possible features included models needs defined using function createCovariateSettings. Function trainPoissonModels actually trains models using Poisson regression LASSO regularization. function can parallelized using package mirai.
code: generateModelCohort(   connectionDetails = connectionDetails,   cdmDatabaseSchema = "main",   resultDatabaseSchema = "main",   resultTable = "model_cohort",   washoutPeriod = 365,   maxObservationPeriod = 15 * 365.25 ) covariateSettings <- FeatureExtraction::createCovariateSettings(   useDemographicsGender = TRUE,   useDemographicsAgeGroup = TRUE,   useConditionOccurrenceAnyTimePrior = TRUE,   useMeasurementAnyTimePrior = TRUE )  mirai::daemons(4) trainPoissonModels(   connectionDetails = connectionDetails,   cdmDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureTable = "model_cohort",   outcomeDatabaseSchema = "main",   outcomeTable = "drugon_exposures",   outcomeIds = 1:40,   covariateSettings = covariateSettings,   saveDir = "models" ) mirai::daemons(0)

title: Running a single simulation
text: Now outcome models generated outcomes interest intermediate step limiting database user-defined cohorts needs executed. purpose step generate stand-alone OMOP database stored locally can queried possibly thousands times execution simulation study. limited database can created using code :
code: extractCohorts(   connectionDetails = connectionDetails,   exposureTable = "drugon_exposures",   exposureIds = 1:4,   cohortTable = "combined_target",   resultDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureDatabaseSchema = "main",   cdmDatabaseSchema = "main" )

title: Running a single simulation
text: can now generate new observation periods, allowing two sub-periods every patient. period cohort start date cohort period (time cohort start cohort end dates). idea keep observation periods simple enforcing one -treatment period per patient. future complex observation periods allowed. new observation periods can generated using code : code instructs PlasmodeSimulation generate every patient table combined_target (generated extractCohorts) new observation period forcing least one year observation prior cohort start date, maximum 15 years total observation period.
code: generateCohortObservationPeriod(   connectionDetails = connectionDetails,   cdmDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureTable = "combined_target",   resultDatabaseSchema = "main",   resultTable = "cohort_observation_period",   maxObservationPeriod = 15 * 365.25,   washoutPeriod = 365 )

title: Running a single simulation
text: next step setting simulation study construct new database limited cohorts interest. datbase stored locally duckDB database queried generation synthetic data simulation. Function limitCdmToCohort ensures records patients cohorts interest new observation periods saved increase efficiency. code executes limiting process stores data directory results:
code: limitCdmToCohort(   connectionDetails = connectionDetails,   cdmDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureDatabaseSchema = "main",   exposureTable = "combined_target",   outcomeDatabaseSchema = "main",   outcomeTable = "drugon_outcomes",   resultDatabaseSchema = "main",   cohortObservationPeriodTable = "cohort_observation_period",   includeOutcomePatients = FALSE,   limitTableNames = "all",   transferTableNames = "all",   saveDir = "results" )

title: Running a single simulation
text: can define new outcome models using already trained models using function modifyExistingModel. Currently, new model can either: Simulate new negative control outcome, , define outcome event rate across entire observation period every patient. Simulate positive control outcome, , define outcome event rate different patient belongs certain cohort interest (exposure) compared . way outcome models trained far, represent negative controls. Treatment covariate models. generate true positive controls based model outcome id 31, first need extract model’s intercept: Assume want new outcome positive control exposures ids 1 2, negative control exposures 3 4. , can first need draw random true rate ratios outcomes 1 2 : Note can use pre-defined rate ratios randomly generate . depends user’s intentions. Now, can defy new model using code : code generate new model, store directory models alongside rest existing models. also update overview.csv file inside models directory information new model. One can easily generate additional models easily following procedure: code generate positive controls based outcome ids 32,…,4032,\dots, 40 exposure ids 1 2, exposure ids 3 4 new outcomes act negative controls. process result simulation 40×4+10×2=18040\times 4 + 10\times 2 = 180 negative controls 10×2=2010\times 2 = 20 positive controls genation benchmark dataset 200 controls.
code: oldIntercept <- readr::read_csv(   "models/overview.csv",   show_col_types = FALSE ) |>   dplyr::filter(outcomeId == 31) |>   dplyr::pull(location) |>   dplyr::readr::read_csv(show_col_types = FALSE) |>   dplyr::filter(column_label == 0) |>   dplyr::pull(estimate) modification <- runif(2, 1.05, 1.2)  newIntercept <- oldIntercept + log(modification) modifyExistingModel(   modelDir = "models",   outcomeId = 31,   exposureIds = c(1, 2),   newBetas = list(     data.frame(column_label = 0, estimate = newIntercept[1]),     data.frame(column_label = 0, estimate = newIntercept[2])   ) ) 32:40 |>   purrr::walk(     .f = modifyExistingModel(       modelDir = "models",       exposureIds = c(1, 2),       newBetas = list(         data.frame(column_label = 0, estimate = newIntercept[1]),         data.frame(column_label = 0, estimate = newIntercept[2])       )     ),     .progress = TRUE   )

title: Running a single simulation
text: can finally generate simulated dataset based real data patients exposure cohorts 1, 2, 3, 4 outcome cohorts 1,…,501,\dots, 50 (40 original outcome cohorts 10 new outcomes) using following code: code use limited database stored results/SimulationDatabase.zip generate simulated dataset size 40,000. result new small stand-alone OMOP database stored disk inside directory results. Note runSampleGeneration can also take advantage multi-threading, using mirai R-package.
code: runSampleGeneration(   simulationDatabaseDir = "results/SimulationDatabase.zip",   size = 4e4,   exposureIds = 1:4,   outcomeIds = 1:50,   covariateSettings = covariateSettings,   modelDir = "models",   saveDir = "results" )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Rekkas (2025). PlasmodeSimulation: Simulating data mapped OMOP-CDM. R package version 0.1.1.
code: @Manual{,   title = {PlasmodeSimulation: Simulating data mapped to OMOP-CDM},   author = {Alexandros Rekkas},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.1}, }

title: Simulating data mapped to OMOP-CDM
text: PlasmodeSimulation R-package creating simulated versions healthcare databases—mapped OMOP Common Data Model—based predefined cohorts. Unlike conventional approaches fully generate synthetic patient-level data (demographics, diagnoses, medications, etc.), plasmode simulations reuse real patient records focus simulating outcomes. Specifically, fitting outcome models observed data, package generates new outcomes every patient. Although still early development, PlasmodeSimulation can already produce benchmark datasets known positive negative controls (.e., treatment–outcome pairs established effect sizes) rigorously evaluate pharmacovigilance methods.
